'''Nathaniel Read''' "'''Nate'''" '''Silver''' (born January 13, 1978) is an American [[statistician]] and [[writer]] who analyzes [[baseball]] (see [[sabermetrics]]) and elections (see [[psephology]]). He is currently the editor-in-chief of [[ESPN]]'s ''[[FiveThirtyEight]]'' blog and a Special Correspondent for [[ABC News]]. Silver first gained public recognition for developing [[PECOTA]],<ref>[[Alan Schwarz]], "Numbers Suggest Mets Are Gambling on Zambrano", [http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A05E3DC173EF931A1575BC0A9629C8B63 ''The New York Times'', August 22, 2004]; [[Alan Schwarz]], "Predicting Futures in Baseball, and the Downside of Damon", [http://www.nytimes.com/2005/11/13/sports/baseball/13score.html ''The New York Times'', November 13, 2005]; Childs Walker, "Baseball Prospectus Makes Predicting Future Thing of Past," ''[[Baltimore Sun]]'', February 21, 2006; Rich Lederer, "An Unfiltered Interview with Nate Silver", [http://baseballanalysts.com/archives/2007/02/an_unfiltered_i.php ''Baseball Analysts'', February 12, 2007]; Tim Murphy, "Timeout with Nate Silver: BP's VP illuminates the sport's fuzzy numbers", [http://www.chicagomaroon.com/2007/5/11/timeout-with-nate-silver-bps-vp-illuminates-the-sports-fuzzy-numbers ''Chicago Maroon'', May 11, 2007]; [[Steven Levitt|Steven D. Levitt]], "Freakonomics: More on Roger Clemens", [http://freakonomics.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/02/18/more-on-roger-clemens ''The New York Times'', February 18, 2008]; and Michael Miner, "The Algorithm Method: Hot Type's coveted Golden BAT award goes to a computer program", [http://www.chicagoreader.com/features/stories/hottype/080327 ''[[Chicago Reader]]'', March 27, 2008].</ref> a system for forecasting the performance and career development of [[Major League Baseball]] players, which he sold to and then managed for [[Baseball Prospectus]] from 2003 to 2009.<ref name="baseballprospectus1">Nate Silver and Kevin Goldstein, "State of the Prospectus: Spring 2009," [http://baseballprospectus.com/article.php?articleid=8653 ''BaseballProspectus.com,'' March 24, 2009].</ref>

After Silver successfully called the outcomes in 49 of the 50 states in the [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008 U.S. Presidential election]], in 2009 Silver was named one of [[Time 100|The World's 100 Most Influential People]] by ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''.<ref name="specials1">{{cite news|last=Stein|first=Joel|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/0,28757,1894410,00.html|title=The World's Most Influential People – The 2009 TIME 100|publisher=''TIME''|accessdate=May 8, 2009}}</ref>

In 2010, the ''FiveThirtyEight'' blog was licensed for publication by ''[[The New York Times]]''.<ref name="FiveThirtyEight.com, June 3, 2010">Nate Silver, "FiveThirtyEight to Partner with New York Times," [http://www.fivethirtyeight.com/2010/06/fivethirtyeight-to-partner-with-new.html FiveThirtyEight.com, June 3, 2010].</ref><ref>[[Brian Stelter]], "Times to Host Blog on Politics and Polls," [http://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/04/business/media/04silver.html ''The New York Times,'' June 3, 2010].</ref> In 2012 and 2013, ''FiveThirtyEight'' won [[Webby Award]]s as the "Best Political Blog" from the [[International Academy of Digital Arts and Sciences]].

In the [[United States presidential election, 2012|2012 United States presidential election]] between Barack Obama and [[Mitt Romney]], Silver correctly predicted the winner of all 50 states and the District of Columbia.<ref name="TelegraphNate">{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/us-election/9662363/Nate-Silver-politics-geek-hailed-for-Barack-Obama-wins-US-election-forecast.html|title=Nate Silver: politics 'geek' hailed for Barack Obama wins US election forecast|publisher=The Telegragh|date=November 7, 2012|accessdate=November 8, 2012|author=Hough, Andrew|location=London}}</ref>

In July 2013, ''FiveThirtyEight'' was sold to ESPN, and Silver became its Editor in Chief.<ref>Brian Stelter, "Nate Silver of FiveThirtyEight Blog Is to Join ESPN Staff," ''The New York Times'', [http://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/20/business/media/nate-silver-blogger-for-new-york-times-is-to-join-espn-staff.html July 19, 2013].</ref> The ESPN-owned ''FiveThirtyEight'' launched on March 17, 2014. The site focused on a broad range of subjects under the rubric of "data journalism".<ref name="March 17, 2014">Nate Silver, "What the Fox Knows," ''FiveThirtyEight,'' [http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/what-the-fox-knows/ March 17, 2014].</ref>

Silver's book, ''[[The Signal and the Noise]]'', was published in September 2012. It subsequently reached [[The New York Times Best Seller list|''The New York Times'' best seller list]] for nonfiction, and was named by [[Amazon.com]] as the #1 best nonfiction book of 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amazon.com/b/ref=sr_aj?node=5917235011&ajr=0 |title=Amazon #1 of 2012 |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=December 5, 2013}}</ref> ''The Signal and the Noise'' won the 2013 [[Phi Beta Kappa Award in Science]].<ref name="pbk.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.pbk.org/home/newsview.aspx?id=998 |title=Phi Beta Kappa book award in science |publisher=Pbk.org |date=October 8, 2013 |accessdate=December 5, 2013}}</ref> The book has been published in nine foreign languages: Chinese (separate editions in traditional and simplified characters), Czech, German, Italian, Polish, Portuguese, Spanish, and Romanian.

Having earned a bachelor's degree from [[The University of Chicago]] in 2000, Silver has since been awarded four honorary doctoral degrees: from [[Ripon College (Wisconsin)|Ripon College]] (2013), [[The New School]] (2013), The [[Katholieke Universiteit Leuven|University of Leuven]] (2013), and [[Amherst College]] (2014).

==Early life==
Silver was born in [[East Lansing, Michigan]], the son of Sally (née Thrun), a community activist, and Brian David Silver, a former chair of the political science department at [[Michigan State University]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/lansingstatejournal/access/1701930301.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jul+05%2C+2008&author=Derek+Wallbank&pub=Lansing+State+Journal&desc=E.L.+native's+predictions+pitch+politics+a+curveball&pqatl=google|title=Wallbank, ''Lansing State Journal''|publisher=Pqasb.pqarchiver.com|date=July 5, 2008|accessdate=August 21, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SI-VqAT4_hYC&pg=PT474&lpg=PT474&dq=Sally+Thrun+Silver&source=bl&ots=7nKOV7bgJI&sig=0RRuzd5T9IaNxpYdV4I6atPNafU&hl=en |title=The Signal and the Noise: Why So Many Predictions Fail-but Some Don't - Nate Silver - Google Books |publisher= |date= |accessdate=December 5, 2013}}</ref> Silver's mother's family, of English and German descent, includes several distinguished men and women, including his maternal great-grandfather, Harmon Lewis, who was president of the Alcoa Steamship Company, Inc.<ref name=intfi1>{{cite web|last=Bloom |first=Nate |url=http://www.interfaithfamily.com/arts_and_entertainment/popular_culture/Interfaith_Celebrities_Nate_Silver_Another_Bond_and_Happy_Endings.shtml |title=Interfaithfamily |publisher=Interfaithfamily |date= |accessdate=December 5, 2013}}</ref> Silver has been known to describe himself as "[[half-Jewish]]" (Silver's father is Jewish).<ref name=intfi1/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1012/82071.html |title=Answer This: Nate Silver - Patrick Gavin |publisher=Politico.Com |date= |accessdate=December 5, 2013}}</ref>

Silver showed a proficiency in math from a young age.<ref>Stephanie Clifford, "Finding Fame With a Prescient Call for Obama," [http://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/10/business/media/10silver.html ''The New York Times,'' November 9, 2008].</ref> According to journalist William Hageman, "Silver caught the baseball bug when he was 6.... It was 1984, the year the [[Detroit Tigers]] won the [[World Series]]. The Tigers became his team and baseball his sport. And if there's anything that goes hand in glove with baseball, it's numbers, another of Silver's childhood interests ("It's always more interesting to apply it to batting averages than algebra class").<ref>William Hageman, "Baseball by the Numbers," ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' (January 4, 2006).</ref>

As a student at [[East Lansing High School]], in 1996 Silver won first place in the State of [[Michigan]] in the 49th annual [[John S. Knight]] Scholarship Contest for senior high school debaters.<ref>"East Lansing Debater Wins Scholarship," ''[[Detroit Free Press]]'' (February 29, 1996). Also see Patricia Montemurri, "Michigan native Nate Silver shows election predictions aren't magic but math," [http://www.freep.com/article/20121111/NEWS15/311110221/Michigan-native-Nate-Silver-shows-election-predictions-aren-t-magic-but-math?odyssey=tab|topnews|text|FRONTPAGE ''Detroit Free Press'', November 11, 2012].</ref>

Silver first showed his [[journalism]] skills as a writer and opinion page editor for ''The Portrait'', East Lansing High School's student newspaper, from 1993–1996.<ref>[http://www.redeyechicago.com/news/redeye-drunk-nate-silver-heres-a-yearbook-photo-before-he-could-drink-20121108,0,6368696.story Link to 1996 high school yearbook photo] with brief resume showing status as writer for ''The Portrait'' for three years and editor for two years. [retrieved November 8, 2012]</ref>

In 2000, Silver graduated with Honors with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in [[economics]] from the [[University of Chicago]]. He also wrote for the ''[[Chicago Weekly|Chicago Weekly News]]'' and the ''[[Chicago Maroon]]''. He spent his third year at the [[London School of Economics]].<ref>Nate Silver, "Random, Pretentious Observations from Europe," [http://www.fivethirtyeight.com/2009/05/random-pretentious-observations-from.html ''FiveThirtyEight.com,'' May 25, 2009].</ref>

==Career==

===Economic consultant: 2000–2003===
After college graduation in 2000, Silver worked for three and a half years as an economic consultant with [[KPMG]] in [[Chicago]]. When asked in 2009, "What is your biggest regret in life?" Silver responded, "Spending four years of my life at a job I didn't like".<ref>Stephen J. Dubner, "FREAK-Quently Asked Questions: Nate Silver," [http://freakonomics.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/03/12/freak-quently-asked-questions-nate-silver/ ''The New York Times'', March 12, 2009].</ref> While employed at KPMG, however, Silver continued to nurture his lifelong interest in baseball and statistics, and on the side he began to work on his [[PECOTA]] system for projecting player performance and careers. He quit his job at KPMG in April 2004 and for a time earned his living mainly by playing [[online poker]].<ref>Rob Kaiser, "Players Place Bets on Poker as Career," [http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2004-10-03/business/0410030372_1_online-poker-poker-sites-interest-in-online-gaming ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', October 3, 2004]. According to ''Sports Illustrated'' writer [[Alexander Wolff]], over a three-year period Silver earned $400,000 from online poker. See Alexander Wolff, "Scorecard: He's ''So'' Predictable," [http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1205991/index.htm ''Sports Illustrated,'' September 17, 2012, p. 15].</ref>

===Baseball analyst: 2003–2008===
In 2003, Silver became a writer for ''[[Baseball Prospectus]]'' (BP), after having sold PECOTA to BP in return for a partnership interest. After resigning from KPMG in 2004, he took the position of Executive Vice-President, later renamed Managing Partner of BP. Silver further developed PECOTA and wrote a weekly column under the heading "Lies, Damned Lies". He applied [[sabermetric]] techniques to a broad range of topics including forecasting the performance of individual players, the economics of baseball, metrics for the [[valuation (finance)|valuation]] of players, and developing an [[Elo rating system]] for Major League baseball.<ref>Nate Silver, "We are Elo?," [http://www.baseballprospectus.com/article.php?articleid=5247 ''BaseballProspectus.com'' (June 28, 2006)] and Nate Silver, "More on Elo," [http://www.baseballprospectus.com/article.php?articleid=5271 ''BaseballProspectus.com'' (July 5, 2006)].</ref>

Between 2003 and 2009, Silver co-authored the ''Baseball Prospectus'' annual book of [[Major League Baseball]] forecasts,<ref>''Baseball Prospectus'' (ISBN 0-7611-3995-8)</ref> as well as other books, including ''Mind Game: How the Boston Red Sox Got Smart, Won a World Series, and Created a New Blueprint for Winning'',<ref>''Mind Game: How the Boston Red Sox Got Smart, Won a World Series, and Created a New Blueprint for Winning'' (New York: Workman Publishers, 2005) (ISBN 0-7611-4018-2)</ref> ''Baseball Between the Numbers'',<ref>''Baseball Between the Numbers'' (New York: Basic Books, 2006) (ISBN 0-465-00596-9)</ref> and ''It Ain't Over 'til It's Over: The Baseball Prospectus Pennant Race Book''.<ref>''It Ain't Over 'til It's Over: The Baseball Prospectus Pennant Race Book'' (New York: Basic Books, 2007) (ISBN 0-465-00284-6)</ref>

He contributed articles about baseball to [[ESPN.com]], ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'', ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', the ''[[New York Sun]]'', and ''[[The New York Times]]''.<ref>Nate Silver, "For Griffey, the Roads Not Taken," [http://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/11/sports/baseball/11score.html ''The New York Times,'' May 11, 2008].</ref>

Silver authored more than 200 articles for Baseball Prospectus.<ref>See [http://www.baseballprospectus.com/news/?author=59 Nate Silver's ''Baseball Prospectus'' article archive] (2003–2009)</ref>

====PECOTA====
{{Main|PECOTA}}
PECOTA (Player Empirical Comparison and Optimization Test Algorithm) is a statistical system that projects the future performance of hitters and pitchers. It is designed primarily for two uses: fans interested in [[fantasy baseball]], and professionals in the baseball business trying to predict the performance and [[valuation (finance)|valuation]] of major league players. Unlike most other baseball projection systems, PECOTA relies on matching a given current player to a set of "comparable" players whose past performance can serve as a guide to how the given current player is likely to perform in the future. Unlike most other such systems, PECOTA also calculates a range of probable performance levels rather than a single predicted value on a given measure such as [[earned run average]] or [[batting average]].

PECOTA projections were first published by [[Baseball Prospectus]] in the 2003 edition of its annual book as well as online by ''BaseballProspectus.com.'' Silver produced the PECOTA forecasts for each [[Major League Baseball]] season from 2003 through 2009.<ref name="baseballprospectus1"/>

===Political analyst and blogger: 2008–present===

====''FiveThirtyEight'' blog====
{{Main|FiveThirtyEight}}
[[File:Natesilver.jpg|thumb|upright|Silver in Washington, D.C., January 19, 2009]]

=====Creation and motivation=====
On November 1, 2007, while still employed by Baseball Prospectus, Silver began publishing a diary under the pseudonym "Poblano" on the progressive political blog ''[[Daily Kos]].''<ref>The first diary was titled, "HRC [Hillary Roddam Clinton] Electability in Purple States, [http://www.dailykos.com/story/2007/11/01/405019/-HRC-Electability-in-Purple-States ''DailyKos'', November 1, 2007].</ref> Silver set out to analyze quantitative aspects of the political game to enlighten a broader audience. Silver reports that "he was stranded in a New Orleans airport when the idea of ''FiveThirtyEight.com'' came to him. 'I was just frustrated with the analysis. ... I saw a lot of discussion about strategy that was not all that sophisticated, especially when it came to quantitative things like polls and demographics'".<ref>Hannah Hayes, "What Will Nate Silver Do Next?," [http://www.uchicago.edu/features/20090126_silver.shtml University of Chicago (webpage feature story), January, 2009].</ref> His forecasts of the 2008 [[United States presidential primary]] elections drew a lot of attention, including being cited by ''[[The New York Times]]'' Op-Ed columnist [[William Kristol]].<ref>William Kristol, "Obama's Path to Victory", [http://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/11/opinion/11kristol.html ''The New York Times,'' February 11, 2008].</ref>

On March 7, 2008, while still writing as "Poblano," Silver established his own blog, ''[[FiveThirtyEight.com]]''. Often colloquially referred to as just 538, the website takes its name from the number of electors in the United States [[Electoral College (United States)|electoral college]].<ref name="faq">{{cite web| url=http://www.fivethirtyeight.com/2008/03/frequently-asked-questions-last-revised.html|title=Frequently Asked Questions|last=Silver|first=Nate|work=FiveThirtyEight.com|accessdate=November 4, 2008|date=August 7, 2008}}</ref>

Silver described his partisan orientation as follows in the [[FAQ]] on his website: "My state [Illinois] has non-partisan registration, so I am not registered as anything. I vote for Democratic candidates the majority of the time (though by no means always). This year, I have been a supporter of Barack Obama".<ref name="FiveThirtyEight.com">Nate Silver, "Frequently Asked Questions, Last Revised 8/7/08," [http://www.fivethirtyeight.com/2008/03/frequently-asked-questions-last-revised.html ''FiveThirtyEight.com''].</ref> With respect to the impartiality of his electoral projections, Silver stated, "Are [my] results biased toward [my] preferred candidates? I hope not, but that is for you to decide. I have tried to disclose as much about my methodology as possible".<ref name="FiveThirtyEight.com"/>

On May 30, 2008, Poblano revealed his identity to ''FiveThirtyEight.com'' readers.<ref>Nate Silver, "No I'm Not [[Chuck Todd]]," [http://www.fivethirtyeight.com/2008/05/no-im-not-chuck-todd.html ''FiveThirtyEight.com,'' May 30, 2008].</ref> On June 1, 2008, Silver published a two-page Op-Ed article in the ''[[New York Post]]'' outlining the rationale underlying his focus on the statistical aspects of politics.<ref>Nate Silver, "Margins of Error," [http://www.nypost.com/seven/06012008/postopinion/opedcolumnists/margins_of_error_113360.htm ''[[New York Post]],'' June 1, 2008.]</ref> He first appeared on national television on [[CNN]]'s ''[[American Morning]]'' on June 13, 2008.<ref>Nate Silver, "CNN Video," [http://www.fivethirtyeight.com/2008/06/cnn-video.html FiveThirtyEight.com, June 13, 2008].</ref>

=====2008 election and aftermath=====
Shortly after the November 4 election, [[ESPN]] writer [[Jim Caple]] observed, "Forget [[Cole Hamels]] and the [[Phillies]]. No one in baseball had a more impressive fall than Nate Silver....  [R]ight now Silver is exhausted. He barely slept the last couple weeks of the campaign—'By the end, it was full-time plus'—and for that matter, he says he couldn't have kept it up had the campaign lasted two days longer. Plus, he has his Baseball Prospectus duties. 'We write our [''Baseball Prospectus 2009''] book from now through the first of the year,' [Silver] said. 'I have a week to relax and then it gets just as busy again. In February 2009 I will just have to find an island in the Caribbean and throw my [[BlackBerry]] in the ocean'".<ref>[[Jim Caple]], "In baseball, and in politics, the numbers don't lie," "Page 2", [http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=caple/081107 ''[[ESPN.com]],'' November 7, 2008].</ref>

Later in November 2008, Silver signed a contract with [[Penguin Books|Penguin Group USA]] to write two books, reportedly for a $700,000 advance.<ref>Leon Neyfakh, "Nate Silver Signs With Penguin In Two Book Deal Worth About $700,000," [http://www.observer.com/2008/media/nate-silver-signs-penguin-two-book-deal-worth-sum-high-six-figures ''New York Observer,'' November 14, 2008].</ref>

Silver was invited to be a speaker at [[TED (conference)|TED 2009]] in February 2009,<ref>See [http://conferences.ted.com/TED2009/program/ TED2009 program] and Shanna Carpenter, "Race and the City: An Exclusive Interview with Nate Silver," [http://blog.ted.com/2009/04/race_and_the_ci.php TED Blog, April 29, 2009].</ref> and keynote speaker at the 2009 [[South by Southwest]] (SXSW) Interactive conference (March 2009).<ref>[[Daniel Terdiman]], "FiveThirtyEight.com's Nate Silver on life post-election," [http://news.cnet.com/8301-13578_3-10196750-38.html [[CNET.com]], March 15, 2009] and Dan Fost, "SXSW: Statistics guru Nate Silver talks Oscars, Manny Ramirez and President Obama," [http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/technology/2009/03/nate-silver-sxs.html ''Los Angeles Times'', March 16, 2009]. See [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KOVM4SIQdmo Video of SXSW Keynote Interview, part 1] and [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FygQVyO4lyE part 2].</ref>

While maintaining his ''FiveThirtyEight.com'' website, in January 2009 Silver began a monthly feature column, "The Data", in ''[[Esquire Magazine|Esquire]]''<ref>{{cite web|last=Silver |first=Nate |url=http://www.esquire.com/archive/features/data/0/10/ |title=The Data |publisher=[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]] |accessdate=May 8, 2009}}</ref> as well as contributed occasional articles to other media such as ''The New York Times''<ref>Nate Silver and [[Andrew Gelman]], "No Country for Close Calls," [http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/19/opinion/19silver.html ''The New York Times'', April 18, 2009].</ref> and the ''Wall Street Journal''.<ref>Nate Silver, "Crunching the Risk Numbers," [http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703481004574646963713065116.html ''Wall Street Journal'', January 8, 2010].</ref>  He also tried his luck in the 2009 [[World Series of Poker]].<ref>Nate Silver, "This Post Brought to You By Poker," [http://www.fivethirtyeight.com/2009/07/this-post-brought-to-you-by-poker.html#comments ''FiveThirtyEight.com,'' July 2, 2009].</ref>

The success of his ''FiveThirtyEight.com'' blog marked the effective end of Silver's career as baseball analyst, though he continued to devote some attention to sports statistics and sports economics in his blog. In March 2009, he stepped down as Managing Partner of Baseball Prospectus and handed over responsibility for producing future PECOTA projections to other Baseball Prospectus staff members.<ref name="baseballprospectus1"/> In April 2009, he appeared as an analyst on ESPN's ''[[Baseball Tonight]]''. After March 2009, he published only two "Lies, Damned Lies" columns on ''BaseballProspectus.com.''

In November 2009, ESPN introduced a new Soccer Power Index (SPi),<ref>[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/spi/rankings ESPN's SPi].</ref> designed by Nate Silver, for predicting the outcome of the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>Nate Silver, "The Purpose of the Soccer Power Index," [http://espn.go.com/soccer/worldcup/news/_/id/4537460/purpose-spi ESPN.com, November 11, 2009] and Nate Silver, "A Guide to ESPN's SPI Ratings," [http://espn.go.com/soccer/worldcup/news/_/id/4447078/guide-espn-spi-ratings ''ESPN.com,'' November 11, 2009]. For a comment see Carl Bialik, "ESPN's New Soccer Rankings," [http://blogs.wsj.com/dailyfix/2009/11/11/the-count-espns-new-soccer-rankings/ ''Wall Street Journal,'' November 11, 2009].</ref> He published a post-mortem after the tournament, comparing his predictions to those of alternative rating systems.<ref>Nate Silver, "SPI in review: How did it do?," [http://soccernet.espn.go.com/world-cup/columns/story/_/id/5392992/ce/us/soccer-power-index-update?cc=5901&ver=us ''ESPN.com,'' July 19, 2010] [Retrieved July 21, 2010].</ref>

In April 2010, in an assignment for ''[[New York Magazine]]'', Silver created a quantitative index of "The Most Livable Neighborhoods in New York".<ref>Nate Silver, "The Most Livable Neighborhoods in New York: a quantitative index of the 50 most satisfying places to live," [http://nymag.com/realestate/neighborhoods/2010/65374/ ''[[New York Magazine]],'' April 11, 2010].</ref>

=====Transition to ''The New York Times''=====
On June 3, 2010, Silver announced on ''FiveThirtyEight.com,''<blockquote>In the near future, the blog will "re-launch" under a NYTimes.com domain. It will retain its own identity (akin to other Times blogs like [[Andrew Ross Sorkin#DealBook|DealBook]]), but will be organized under the News:Politics section. Once this occurs, content will no longer be posted at ''FiveThirtyEight.com'' on an ongoing basis, and the blog will re-direct to the new [[URL]]. In addition, I will be contributing content to the print edition of ''The New York Times'', and to the ''Sunday Magazine''. The partnership agreement, which is structured as a license, has a term of three years.<ref name="FiveThirtyEight.com, June 3, 2010"/><ref>For more information about the working agreement between ''The Times'' and Nate Silver's blog, see Mallory Jean Tenore, "FiveThirtyEight’s Nate Silver adjusts to New York Times, 6 months after joining the newsroom," [http://www.poynter.org/latest-news/top-stories/120212/fivethirtyeights-nate-silver-adjusts-to-new-york-times-as-a-blogger-6-months-after-joining-the-newsroom/ ''Poynter,'' June 3, 2011], and Margaret Sullivan, "On Identifying a Rape Victim, Naming a Prophet, and Nate Silver’s Role," [http://publiceditor.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/09/21/on-identifying-a-rape-victim-naming-a-prophet-and-nate-silvers-role-the-public-editor/ ''The New York Times,'' September 21, 2012].</ref></blockquote>

''The New York Times'' "FiveThirtyEight: Nate Silver's Political Calculus" commenced on August 25, 2010, with the publication of "New Forecast Shows Democrats Losing 6 to 7 Senate Seats".<ref>Nate Silver, "New Forecast Shows Democrats Losing 6 to 7 Senate Seats," [http://fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/08/25/new-forecast-shows-democrats-losing-6-to-7-senate-seats/ FiveThirtyEight/NYT, August 25, 2010].</ref> From that date the blog focused almost exclusively on forecasting the outcomes of the 2010 [[United States Senate elections, 2010|U.S. Senate]] and [[United States House of Representatives elections, 2010|U.S. House of Representatives]] elections as well as [[United States gubernatorial elections, 2010|state gubernatorial]] contests. Silver's ''Times Sunday Magazine'' feature first appeared on November 19, 2010, under the heading "Go Figure".<ref>Nate Silver, "Go Figure: Who's No. 1?" [http://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/21/magazine/21fob-gofigure-t.html NY Times Magazine, November 19, 2010].</ref> It was later titled "Acts of Mild Subversion".<ref>For example, Nate Silver, "How to Beat the Salad Bar," [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/20/magazine/mag-20Subversion-t.html ''The New York Times,'' March 17, 2011].</ref>

While blogging for ''The Times,'' Silver also worked on his book about prediction, which was published in September 2012. At that time, Silver began to drop hints that after 2012 he would turn his attention to matters other than detailed statistical forecasting of elections. As reported in ''New York'' magazine: " 'I view my role now as providing more of a macro-level skepticism, rather than saying this poll is good or this poll is evil,' he says. And in four [years], he might be even more macro, as he turns his forecasting talents to other fields. 'I’m 97 percent sure that the FiveThirtyEight model will exist in 2016,' he says, 'but it could be someone else who’s running it or licensing it.'"<ref>Jason Zengerle, "The. Polls. Have. Stopped. Making. Any. Sense.", [http://nymag.com/news/features/election-polls-2012-10/ ''New York,'' September 30. 2012].</ref>

During the last year of ''FiveThirtyEight's'' license to ''The Times,'' it drew a very large volume of [[web traffic|online traffic]] to the paper:<blockquote>The Times does not release traffic figures, but a spokesperson said yesterday that Silver’s blog provided a significant—and significantly growing, over the past year—percentage of Times pageviews. This fall, visits to the Times’ political coverage (including FiveThirtyEight) have increased, both absolutely and as a percentage of site visits. But FiveThirtyEight’s growth is staggering: where earlier this year, somewhere between 10 and 20 percent of politics visits included a stop at FiveThirtyEight, last week that figure was 71 percent.</blockquote>

<blockquote>But Silver’s blog has buoyed more than just the politics coverage, becoming a significant traffic-driver for the site as a whole. Earlier this year, approximately 1 percent of visits to the New York Times included ''FiveThirtyEight.'' Last week, that number was 13 percent. Yesterday, it was 20 percent. That is, one in five visitors to the sixth-most-trafficked U.S. news site took a look at Silver’s blog.<ref>Marc Tracy, "Nate Silver Is a One-Man Traffic Machine for the Times," ''[[The New Republic]]'', November 6, 2012.</ref></blockquote>

=====Departure from ''The Times''=====
In an online chat session a week after the 2012 election Silver commented: "As tempting as it might be to pull a [[Jim Brown]]/[[Sandy Koufax]] and just mic-drop/retire from elections forecasting, I expect that we'll be making forecasts in 2014 and 2016. Midterm elections can be dreadfully boring, unfortunately. But the 2016 [[Republican Party (United States)|G.O.P.]] primary seems almost certain to be epic".<ref>"Skew Yourselves: Nate Silver Is Here To Answer Your Questions," [http://deadspin.com/5960364/skew-yourselves-nate-silver-is-here-to-answer-your-questions ''[[Deadspin]],'' November 14, 2012].</ref> In late November 2012, ''Times'' executive editor [[Jill Abramson]] declared her wish to keep Silver and his blog: "We would love to have Nate continue to be part of the New York Times family, and to expand on what he does," she said. "We know he began in sports anyway, so it is not an exclusively political product. I am excited to talk to Nate when he finishes his book tour about ways to expand that kind of reporting".<ref>Alex Weprin, "The New York Times Wants To Keep Nate Silver, ‘Expand On What He Does’", ''[[Mediabistro.com|Mediabistro]],'' [http://www.mediabistro.com/fishbowlny/the-new-york-times-wants-to-keep-nate-silver-expand-on-what-he-does_b72049 November 27, 2012]. Also see Connor Simpson, "What the Future Holds for Nate Silver at The New York Times," ''[[The Atlantic|Atlantic Wire]],'' [http://www.theatlanticwire.com/business/2012/11/what-future-holds-nate-silver-and-new-york-times/59369/ November 27, 2012].</ref>

On July 22, 2013, ESPN announced that it had acquired ownership of the ''FiveThirtyEight'' website and brand, and that "Silver will serve as editor-in-chief of the site and will build a team of journalists, editors, analysts and contributors in the coming months".<ref>"Nate Silver makes move to ESPN," [[ESPN.com]], [http://espn.go.com/espn/story/_/id/9499752/nate-silver-joins-espn-multifaceted-role July 22, 2013]; "Nate Silver – Renowned Statistician, Author and Founder of FiveThirtyEight – Joins ESPN in Multi-Faceted Role," [http://frontrow.espn.go.com/2013/07/nate-silver-renowned-statistician-author-and-founder-of-fivethirtyeight-joins-espn-in-multi-faceted-role/ ESPN Front Row, July 22, 2013].</ref>

''The New York Times'' public editor [[Margaret Sullivan]] wrote upon Silver's decision to leave for ESPN: <blockquote>I don’t think Nate Silver ever really fit into the Times culture and I think he was aware of that. He was, in a word, disruptive. Much like the Brad Pitt character in the movie “Moneyball” disrupted the old model of how to scout baseball players, Nate disrupted the traditional model of how to cover politics.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sullivan|first=Margaret|title=Nate Silver Went Against the Grain for Some at The Times|url=http://publiceditor.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/07/22/nate-silver-went-against-the-grain-for-some-at-the-times/?smid=tw-share|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=23 July 2013|date=July 22, 2013}}</ref></blockquote>
She added, "A number of traditional and well-respected Times journalists disliked his work".<ref>On the culture clash within ''The Times,'' also see John Sides, "One Irony of Nate Silver’s Leaving the New York Times," ''[[Washington Monthly]]'', [http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/ten-miles-square/2013/07/one_irony_of_nate_silvers_leav045992.php# July 24, 2013]; and Jim Naureckas, "Nate Silver Didn't Fit In at the New York Times Because He Believed in the Real World," [[Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting|FAIR]], [http://www.fair.org/blog/2013/07/24/nate-silver-didnt-fit-in-at-the-new-york-times-because-he-believed-in-the-real-world/ July 24, 2013].</ref> Later, Sullivan wrote in ''The Times'' that "I don’t feel so good about not being able to investigate every complaint from every individual reader fully, or about making some misjudgments in individual posts — my Nate Silver commentary, among others, has probably been off-base...".<ref>Although she linked to her "Nate Silver Went Against the Grain" article, Sullivan did not specify in what ways she had been off-base. See Margaret Sullivan, "A Year in the Life of a Watchdog," ''The New York Times,'' September 1, 2013.</ref>

[[New York (magazine)|''New York'']] magazine reported that executive editor Jill Abramson "put on a full-court press" to keep Silver at ''The Times'' and that "for Abramson, Silver was a tentpole attraction for her favorite subject, national politics, and brought the kind of buzz she thought valuable," but the company's CEO and President [[Mark Thompson (television executive)|Mark Thompson]] "confirmed that keeping Silver was not at the top of his agenda". When ''FiveThirtyEight'' was relaunched under ESPN's ownership on March 17, 2014, Silver outlined the scope of topics that would be covered under the rubric of "data journalism":<ref name="March 17, 2014"/> <blockquote>We’ve expanded our staff from two full-time journalists to 20 and counting. <blockquote>Our team also has a broad set of skills and experience in methods that fall under the rubric of data journalism. ====''FiveThirtyEight's'' election forecasts====

=====2008 U.S. elections=====
{{Main|FiveThirtyEight}}
In March 2008, Silver established his blog ''FiveThirtyEight.com,'' in which he developed a system for tracking polls and forecasting the outcome of the 2008 [[general election]]. At the same time, he continued making forecasts of the [[Democratic Party (United States) presidential primaries, 2008|2008 Democratic primary elections]]. That several of his forecasts based on [[demographic analysis]] proved to be substantially more accurate than those of the professional [[pollsters]] gained visibility and professional credibility for "Poblano," the pseudonym that Silver was then using.<ref>See, most notably, Mark Blumenthal, "The Poblano Model," [http://www.nationaljournal.com/njonline/mp_20080507_8254.php ''[[National Journal]],'' May 8, 2008].</ref>

After the North Carolina and Indiana primaries on May 6 the popularity of ''FiveThirtyEight.com'' "really exploded. Silver recalls the scenario: 'I know the polls show it's really tight in NC, but we think Obama is going to win by thirteen, fourteen points, and he did. ... Any time you make a prediction like that people give you probably too much credit for it.... But after that [Silver's and the website's popularity] started to really take off. It's pretty nonlinear, once you get one mention in the mainstream media, other people [quickly follow suit]'".<ref>Sean Redmond, "Numerical Order: Famed Statistician Nate Silver Discusses the Future of His Near-Flawless Forecasts," [http://chicagoweekly.net/2009/01/09/numerical-order-famed-statistician-nate-silver-discusses-the-future-of-his-near-flawless-forecasting/ ''[[Chicago Weekly]]'', January 9, 2009]. On this point see also Silver's discussion in Megan Garber, "Talking Shop: Nate Silver," [http://www.cjr.org/campaign_desk/talking_shop_nate_silver.php ''Columbia Journalism Review'', November 11, 2008].</ref>

As a [[CNET]] reporter wrote on election eve, "Even though Silver launched the site as recently as March, its straightforward approach, daring predictions, and short but impressive track record has put it on the map of political sites to follow. ''[[The Washington Post]]'' featured Silver in its 14th annual election prediction contest this year, and he'll be reporting on Tuesday night's results with [[Dan Rather]] on [[HDNet]]".<ref>Stephanie Condon, "Q & A: The Formula Behind FiveThirtyEight," [http://news.cnet.com/8301-13578_3-10080885-38.html?part=rsssubj=newstag=2547-1_3-0-20 ''CNET News'', November 3, 2008].</ref>

Silver's final 2008 presidential election forecast accurately predicted the winner of 49 of the 50 states as well as the [[Washington, D.C.|District of Columbia]] (missing only the prediction for Indiana). As his model predicted, the races in [[Missouri]] and [[North Carolina]] were particularly close. He also correctly predicted the winners of every [[United States Senate|U.S. Senate]] race.  The accuracy of his predictions won him further acclaim, including abroad,<ref>Editorial, "In Praise of ... Nate Silver," [http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2008/nov/06/us-elections-nate-silver-predictions ''The Guardian'', November 6, 2008].</ref> and added to his reputation as a leading political prognosticator.<ref>Stephanie Clifford, "Finding Fame With a Prescient Call for Obama," [http://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/10/business/media/10silver.html?scp=5&sq=Stephanie%20Clifford&st=cse ''The New York Times'', November 10, 2008].</ref>

[[Barack Obama presidential campaign, 2008|Barack Obama's 2008 presidential campaign]] signed off on a proposal to share all of its private polling with Silver. After signing a confidentiality agreement, Silver was granted access to hundreds of polls the campaign had conducted.<ref>{{cite book |title= The Victory Lab|last=  Issenberg|first=Sasha |authorlink= |year= |publisher= [[Crown Publishing Group]] |location= |isbn=030795479X |page= 290 |pages= |accessdate=September 28, 2012 |url=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=BuzzFeed Politics |url=http://www.buzzfeed.com/buzzfeedpolitics/obama-campaign-shared-08-polling-with-silver |title="Obama Campaign Shared '08 Polling With Silver" ''BuzzFeed,'' September 5, 2012 |publisher=Buzzfeed.com |date= |accessdate=December 5, 2013}}</ref>

=====2010 U.S. elections=====
{{Main|FiveThirtyEight#2010 U.S. mid-term elections}}
Shortly after FiveThirtyEight relocated to ''The New York Times,'' Silver introduced his prediction models for the 2010 elections to the U.S. Senate, the U.S. House of Representatives, and state Governorships. Each of these models relied initially on a combination of electoral history, demographics, and polling. Silver eventually published detailed forecasts and analyses of the results for all three sets of elections. He correctly predicted the winner in 34 of the 37 contested Senate races.  His 2010 congressional mid-term predictions were not as accurate as those made in 2008, but were still within the reported [[confidence interval]]. Silver predicted a Republican pickup of 54 seats in the House of Representatives; the GOP won 63 seats. Of the 37 gubernatorial races, FiveThirtyEight correctly predicted the winner of 36.<ref>Micah Cohen, "38 Days Later," ''The New York Times,'' [http://fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/12/10/38-days-later/ December 10, 2010]</ref>

=====2012 U.S. elections=====
{{Main|FiveThirtyEight#2012_U.S._elections|l1=FiveThirtyEight: 2012 U.S. elections}}
Although throughout 2011 Silver devoted a lot of attention on his blog to the 2012 Republican party primaries, his first effort to handicap the 2012 Presidential general election appeared as the cover story in ''The New York Times Magazine'' a year prior to the election: "Is Obama Toast? Handicapping the 2012 Election".<ref>Nate Silver, "Is Obama Toast? Handicapping the 2012 Election," [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/06/magazine/nate-silver-handicaps-2012-election.html ''The New York Times Magazine'', November 6, 2011].</ref> Accompanying the online release of this article, Silver also published "Choose Obama's Re-Election Adventure", an interactive toy that allowed readers to predict the outcome of the election based on their assumptions about three variables: President Obama's favorability ratings, the rate of GDP growth, and how conservative the Republican opponent would be.<ref>Nate Silver, "Choose Obama's Re-Election Adventure," [http://fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/11/03/choose-obamas-re-election-adventure/ ''The New York Times'', November 3, 2011].</ref> This analysis stimulated a lot of critical discussion.<ref>For a partial bibliography, see Micah Cohen, "Reads and Reactions," [http://fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/11/19/reads-reactions-14/ ''The New York Times'', November 19, 2011].</ref>

While publishing numerous stories on the Republican primary elections, in mid-February 2012 Silver reprised and updated his previous ''Magazine'' story with another one, "What Obama Should Do Next".<ref>Nate Silver, "Why Obama Will Embrace the 99 Percent," [http://www.vanityfair.com/business/features/2011/09/europe-201109 ''The New York Times Magazine'', February 15, 2012].</ref> This story painted a more optimistic picture of President Obama's re-election chances. Silver published the first iteration of his 2012 general election forecasts on June 7, 2012. According to the model, at that time Barack Obama was projected to win 291 electoral votes—21 more than the 270 required for a majority. ==Book==
{{main|The Signal and the Noise}}
[[File:Nate Silver at SXSW 2013.jpg|Nate Silver at SXSW 2013|thumb|right|Silver signing a copy of ''The Signal and the Noise'' at [[South by Southwest|SXSW]] 2013]]

''The Signal and The Noise'' was published in the United States on September 27, 2012. It reached the ''New York Times'' Best Sellers list as #12 for non-fiction hardback books after its first week in print. It dropped to #20 in the second week, before rising to #13 in the third, and remaining on the non-fiction hardback top 15 list for the following 13 weeks, with a highest weekly ranking of #4.<ref>{{cite news|last=Cowles |first=Gregory |url=http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/hardcover-nonfiction/list.html |title=New York Times Best Sellers List |publisher=Nytimes.com |date= |accessdate=December 5, 2013}}</ref> Sales increased after the election on November 6, jumping 800% and becoming the second best seller on ''Amazon''.<ref>Jason Notte, "Nate Silver sees soaring Amazon book sales: The FiveThirtyEight blogger's confident and steadfast Obama forecast gets readers curious and critics furious", [http://money.msn.com/top-stocks/post.aspx?post=3d424e42-2010-4c0d-abed-340c55f00240&ocid=ansmony11 ''[[MSN Money]],'' November 8, 2012].</ref>

The book describes methods of mathematical model building using probability and statistics. Silver takes a big-picture approach to using statistical tools, combining sources of unique data (e.g., timing a minor league ball player's fastball using a radar gun), with historical data and principles of sound statistical analysis; Silver argues that many of these are violated by many pollsters and pundits who nonetheless have important media roles. Case studies in the book include baseball, elections, [[climate change]], the financial crash, poker, and weather forecasting. These different topics illustrate different statistical principles. As a reviewer in ''The New York Times'' notes: "It’s largely about evaluating predictions in a variety of fields, from finance to weather to epidemiology. We learn about a handful of successes: when, for instance, meteorologists predict a hurricane’s landfall 72 hours in advance.... But mostly we learn about failures. It turns out we’re not even close to predicting the next catastrophic earthquake or the spread of the next killer bird flu, despite the enormous amounts of brainpower trained on these questions in the past few decades".<ref>Noam Scheiber, "Known Unknowns: ''The Signal and the Noise,'' by Nate Silver", ''The New York Times,'' [http://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/04/books/review/the-signal-and-the-noise-by-nate-silver.html]</ref>

==Criticism==
Silver has been criticized for inaccurate predictions. In January 2010, journalist and blogger [[Colby Cosh]] criticized Silver's performance during the [[United States Senate special election in Massachusetts, 2010|Massachusetts special Senate election]], saying he was "still arguing as late as Thursday afternoon that Coakley was the clear favourite; he changed his mind at midnight that evening and acknowledged that Scott Brown had a puncher’s chance."<ref>{{cite news|last=Cosh|first=Colby|title=Mr. Overrated|url=http://www2.macleans.ca/2010/01/19/mr-overrated/|accessdate=November 6, 2012|newspaper=Macleans|date=January 19, 2010}}</ref> (Brown won the election.)

Silver's quantitative focus on polling data, without insight from experience in political organizing or journalism, has been a recurring critique from experienced commentators. ''Huffington Post'' columnist Geoffrey Dunn described Silver as someone who "has never organized a precinct in his life, much less walked one, pontificating about the dynamics in the electoral processes as if he actually understood them."<ref>{{cite news|last=Dunn|first=Geoffrey|title=FiveThirtyHate?: Nate Silver Gets His Numbers Crossed in Charlotte|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/geoffrey-dunn/fivethirtyhate-nate-silve_b_1863634.html|accessdate=November 3, 2012|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=September 7, 2012}}</ref>

Considerable criticism during the 2012 elections came from political conservatives, who argued that Silver's election projections were politically biased against [[Mitt Romney]], the Republican candidate for President.<ref>Gregory Ferenstein, "Why Pundits and Politicians Hate NYT Election Forecaster Nate Silver," [http://techcrunch.com/2012/10/30/why-pundits-and-politicians-hate-nyt-election-forecaster-nate-silver/ [[TechCrunch]], October 30, 2012].</ref> For example, Silver was accused of applying a double standard to his treatment of [[Rasmussen Reports]] polls, such as a 2010 analysis asserting a statistical bias in its methodology.<ref>Nate Silver, "Rasmussen Polls Were Biased and Inaccurate; Quinnipiac, SurveyUSA Performed Strongly," [http://fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/11/04/rasmussen-polls-were-biased-and-inaccurate-quinnipiac-surveyusa-performed-strongly/ FiveThirtyEight, November 4, 2010].</ref> Mendy Finkel of ''[[Daily Caller]]'' wrote that "Silver rigged his entire pollster ratings for the sole purpose of lowering Rasmussen's rank".<ref>{{cite news|last=Finkel|first=Mendy|title=Nate Silver’s Rasmussen obsession|url=http://dailycaller.com/2012/11/02/nate-silvers-rasmussen-obsession|accessdate=November 3, 2012|newspaper=Daily Caller|date=November 2, 2012}}</ref> Josh Jordan wrote in ''[[National Review]]'' that Silver clearly favored Obama and adjusted the weight he gave polls "based on what [he] think[s] of the pollster and the results and not based on what is actually inside the poll".<ref>{{cite news|last=Jordan|first=Josh|title=Nate Silver’s Flawed Model|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/331192/nate-silver-s-flawed-model-josh-jordan|accessdate=November 3, 2012|newspaper=National Review|date=October 22, 2012}}</ref>

On [[MSNBC]]'s ''[[Morning Joe]]'', host [[Joe Scarborough]] stated that Silver's prediction that day of a 73.6% chance of a win for Obama greatly exceeded the confidence of the Obama campaign itself, which Scarborough equated to that of the Romney campaign, both believing "they have a 50.1 percent chance of winning", and calling Silver an "ideologue" and a "joke". Silver responded with the offer of a $1,000 wager (for charity) over the outcome of the election. ''The New York Times'' public editor Margaret Sullivan, while defending Silver's analysis, characterized the wager as "a bad idea" as it gave the appearance of a partisan motive for Silver, and "inappropriate" for someone perceived as a ''Times'' journalist (although Silver was not a member of the newspaper's staff).<ref>{{cite news|last=Sullivan|first=Margaret|title=Under Attack, Nate Silver Picks the Wrong Defense|url=http://publiceditor.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/11/01/under-attack-nate-silver-picks-the-wrong-defense/|accessdate=November 3, 2012|newspaper=New York Times|date=November 1, 2012}}. For a critical comment see Andrew Beaujon, "New York Times wants to hold Nate Silver to newsroom standards", [http://www.poynter.org/latest-news/mediawire/194020/new-york-times-wants-to-hold-nate-silver-to-newsroom-standards/ [[Poynter Institute|Poynter]], November 2, 2012].</ref><ref>For discussion of another "pundits vs. Nate Silver" case, see John Cassidy, "Brooks vs. Silver: The Limits of Forecasting Elections," [http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/johncassidy/2012/10/david-brooks-v-nate-silver-prediction-polls.html [[The New Yorker]], October 24, 2012].</ref>

After a post-election appearance by Silver on Joe Scarborough's ''Morning Joe'', Scarborough published what he called a "(semi) apology," in which he concluded:

{{Quote|I won’t apologize to Mr. Silver for predicting an outcome that I had also been predicting for a year. But I do need to tell Nate I’m sorry for leaning in too hard and lumping him with pollsters whose methodology is as rigorous as the Simpsons’ strip mall physician, Dr. Nick. For those sins (and a multitude of others that I’m sure I don’t even know about), I am sorry.

Politics is a messy sport. And just as ball players who drink beer and eat fried chicken in dugouts across America can screw up the smartest sabermatrician’s forecast, Nate Silver’s formula is sure to let his fervent admirers down from time to time. But judging from what I saw of him this morning, Nate is a grounded guy who admits as much in his book. I was too tough on him and there’s a 84.398264% chance I will be less dismissive of his good work in the future".<ref>Joe Scarborough, "My (Semi) Apology to Nate Silver," ''Politico,'' [http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1112/84115.html November 21, 2012].</ref>}}

Silver's nondisclosure of the details of his analytical model has resulted in some skepticism. [[The Washington Post|''Washington Post'']] journalist [[Ezra Klein]] wrote: "There are good criticisms to make of Silver's model, not the least of which is that, while Silver is almost tediously detailed about what's going on in the model, he won’t give out the code, and without the code, we can't say with certainty how the model works."<ref>{{cite news|last=Klein|first=Ezra|title=The Nate Silver backlash|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/ezra-klein/wp/2012/10/30/the-nate-silver-backlash/|accessdate=November 3, 2012|newspaper=Washington Post|date=October 30, 2012}}</ref> Colby Cosh wrote that the model "is proprietary and irreproducible. That last feature makes it unwise to use Silver's model as a straw stand-in for "science", as if the model had been fully specified in a peer-reviewed journal".<ref>"Nate Silver and the Trials of a Forecaster," [http://www.threehundredeight.com/2012/11/nate-silver-and-trials-of-forecaster.html ThreeHundredEight.com, November 6, 2012].</ref>

On August 13, 2014, Silver was criticized for comparing his own experience of being arrested with those of journalists and members of the public during protests and riots in response to the [[shooting of Michael Brown]] in [[Ferguson, Missouri]] <ref name="gawker.com">"Nate Silver, Inspired by Ferguson, Tells Idiotic Arrest Story" [http://gawker.com/nate-silver-inspired-by-events-in-ferguson-tells-idio-1621363315].</ref><ref name="politico.com">"Nate Silver Is Sorry for Telling His ‘Misguided and Naive’ Burrito Arrest Story During the Ferguson Protests" [http://www.politico.com/blogs/media/2014/08/how-not-to-cover-ferguson-nate-silver-edition-193951.html].</ref><ref name="nymag.com">"Nate Silver Tells Tone-Deaf Burrito Arrest Story Amid Ferguson Protests, Gets Epically Burned" [http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2014/08/nate-silver-ferguson-burrito-arrest-traffic-leak.html].</ref> In a series of eight consecutive postings to [[Twitter]], Silver recounted a story of being arrested but later placating officers with the words "sorry guys, was just stressed out and having a rough day ... my bad!", after which he was given back his burrito to eat in his cell and received a ride home from officers.<ref name="gawker.com"/><ref name="nymag.com"/> Silver later publicly apologized, describing his posts as being "misguided and naive".<ref name="politico.com"/>
